Award.AwardTitle: The Noyce Connection: Building a Community of Science and Mathematics Teacher Educators

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the nation's challenge to recruit and prepare highly qualified STEM teachers to serve school districts that have the greatest need. Community-building efforts are increasing access to the strategies and resources developed through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, enabling futher implementation of effective practices. The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) is providing resources and building a network to share and exchange ideas about effective STEM teacher education programs, practices, and strategies for attracting, preparing, and supporting science and mathematics teachers and retaining them in the teaching workforce in high need school districts. The project serves the awardees of the NSF Noyce program, which includes over 200 higher education institutions. In addition, through proposal preparation workshops/Webinars, the project reaches STEM faculty from another 100 institutions who might be interested in developing K-12 science and mathematics teacher education programs. This multi-faceted approach enables extensive dissemination of ideas and strategies within the greater STEM teacher education community, thus broadening the impact of Noyce program.

The specific objectives include:
1) Co-sponsoring and implementing the 2014 NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship conference for faculty, administrators, student scholars, and STEM teachers who are supported through the Noyce program;
2) Developing and implementing Webinars that will facilitate information sharing about campus-based Noyce Program strategies and practices;
3) Developing an online resource locator to share papers, videos, tools, and documents developed by and of interest to the Noyce community;
4) Producing a short Voices from the Field video series featuring former Noyce Scholars or Fellows who are now teaching in high needs schools for teacher recruitment and public awareness purposes;
5) Co-sponsoring and implementing proposal preparation workshops and Webinars for prospective Noyce grantees; and
6) Developing and maintaining an NSF Noyce Program website that includes: conference information; an online project locator with information about the projects; and profiles of Noyce Scholars and Fellows.

The project provides a conference, webinars, and online resources to help science, engineering, technology, and mathematics (STEM) faculty develop and/or strengthen science and mathematics K-12 teacher education programs and to form partnerships with high-need schools. The conference and resources focus on (a) recruiting and preparing STEM undergraduate majors and professionals for teaching careers in elementary and secondary public schools; and (b) building effective partnerships with public schools, particularly with high need schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) provided resources and networking activities for the National Science Foundation (NSF) Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce) to help grantees identify and disseminate information about effective practices and strategies for recruiting, preparing, and mentoring preservice science and mathematics teachers and retaining them in the K-12 teaching workforce in high need schools and districts. The NSF Noyce Program responds to the critical need to increase the number of K-12 science and mathematics teachers by encouraging talented college and university science and mathematics majors and professionals with science and mathematics degrees to pursue teaching careers in elementary and secondary schools.

Intellectual Merit

Project activities included:

***Co-sponsoring and implementing the 2014 NSF Robert Noyce annual conference for faculty, administrators, student scholars, and STEM teachers who are supported by the Noyce program. The conference program and workshop abstracts are included on the program website (http://nsfnoyce.org/files/2014/06/2014Noyce-Conference-Program_web_version.pdf).

***Producing the Voices from the Field video series featuring short videos that highlights the overall NSF Noyce Program and 10 former Noyce Scholars or Fellows who are now teaching in high-need schools. These videos are useful for STEM teacher recruitment and public awareness purposes (http://app.nsfnoyce.org/voices-series/).

***Co-sponsoring and implementing 4 online proposal preparation workshops and webinars for prospective NSF Noyce grantees. The 4 webinars had over 500 registrants.

***Developing and maintaining an NSF Noyce Program website that includes conference information, an online project locator with information about 547 Noyce projects, and profiles of 877 Noyce Scholars and Fellows (http://app.nsfnoyce.org/project-locator/ and http://app.nsfnoyce.org/profiles/).

Broader Impacts

***The 2014 Noyce Conference included 480 participants from 219 institutions, including 280 college and university faculty, staff and other educators. In addition, the conference was attended by 200 current or former Noyce Scholars or Fellows.

***The conference included 62 workshops, 5 plenary sessions that include poster and networking sessions. One hundred and fifty-one (151) Noyce faculty and staff, as well as 37 Scholars and Fellows submitted abstracts and presented posters. The 2014 Noyce conference sessions focused on

(a)   innovative Noyce Program practices and teacher preparation models, including alternative certification;

(b)   supporting and mentoring new teachers;

(c)   teacher leadership;

(d)   K-12 partnerships;

(e)   project management;

(f)    recruitment and marketing strategies;

(g)   research and evaluation; and

(h)   resources for teachers.

Conference evaluation forms were distributed and collected on site during the last session of the conference. The evaluation response rate was 31.3% or 150/480. The rating scale for all the 2014 Noyce Conference sessions and workshops was excellent (5), very good (4), good (3), fair (2), and poor (1).

***The mean score for the plenary sessions ranged from 3.0 to 4.9, with an overall mean of 3.7 in the good plus range.

***The mean score for the poster sessions were in the good plus range, 3.5 and 3.6, respectively for the project and student poster sessions.

***The overall mean for all the workshops was 3.9, in the very good range. Of the 62 workshops 27 or 43% had a mean of 4.0 (very good) or above. Only 6 workshops had a mean score below the good (3.0) range.

***The mean rating for the networking session was 3.8 and the mean rating for the new awardee session was 3.8, in the good plus range.

Evaluation results from the 2014 Noyce conference indicated that the most valuable part of the conference for faculty and staff and Noyce Fellows was comparing ideas, learning from one another, and networking. A previous external evaluation of Noyce conferences indicated that the large majority of project staff gained ideas for program improvement through the Noyce conferences. Most of these ideas focused on specific program improvements, increasing and improving recruitment and retention of participants in their programs, and building local and regional networks to recruit and prepare K-12 STEM teachers. The large majority of project personnel identified specific resources they obtained through the conferences, including reading materials, references, and reports, as well as websites and organizations.

Similarly, the large majority of project personnel gained contact persons through the program. They identified specific persons or groups of persons that they planned to contact after the conference to help support the development and improvement of their program.

For the current and former Noyce Scholars or Fellows, the most valuable part of the conference appears to be the workshops. Scholars and Fellows who responded to the evaluation question indicated that they plan to use workshop resources or strategies in their class, including websites, reading materials, references, and reports.

Google Analytics indicated that between September 1, 2014 and August 28, 2017, the Noyce website had 91,453 sessions; 71,590 users; and 200,743 page views.
